title: Is it worth it to get two Master's degrees?
Finishing up my Bachelor's this semester and going through the process of getting ready for my Master's. There are two programs that are very appealing to me and would both be beneficial in my future career. I favor one slightly more than the other, but I can get the one I favor less for 50% of the cost because of the internship I am currently in.

Would it make sense to complete the discounted one, and get the other afterwards if I still thought it would be beneficial? Each program is an online intensive that takes between a year and a year and a half to complete, so theoretically I could have a Bachelor's and two Master's by the time I'm 25, which sounds worth it to me. I'm a first-gen college student and the only person I know from my family who has pursued a graduate degree, so I really don't know what is standard. Any advice?

concern:
title: I hate it when professors say something is "easy"
Literally the quickest way to make a student feel bad about themselves because they don't quite understand or it's not actually "easy" for them.

I was told recently during office hours for a CS class that the file and code I wrote was not needed and that I was doing it wrong and all I had to do was this and that and whatever and she ended by saying "It's easy." 

That made me feel like shit cause I didn't know how to do it despite it being "easy" and I was in a depressing mood for the rest of the day and the following day as well. 

Saying that an assignment is easy is just unnecessary. You have no idea what someone's struggles are, with the content/class **and** outside of that as well. While an assignment could technically be easy, that doesn't mean it's easy for someone to get up and sit down to do the assignment if they're struggling with their mental health, family issues etc.

concern:
title: PSA: “do not disturb” means DO NOT DISTURB (this is a post about respect)
Living in a dorm is hell as it is. I can’t tell you how many times people have disrespected the “do not disturb” sign. 

If somebody has that kind of sign, kindly DO NOT DO IT AND WALK AWAY. They don’t want to talk to you or anybody else. Even if you’re an RA, just email or text. Why? Because I’m sleeping. Or I’m taking a test. Or I’m doing homework. And I need to concentrate.

And you… you decide to be the snide mufker who knocks on my door with the “do not disturb” sign. The “you” I’m referring to is the guy who hosts dorm parties every Tuesday night, and knocks on my door to ask if I was the one who called the cop. Comes to ask me random questions at 3am. Or another one, my neighbors who are curious about something.

*Does no mean no?* Then why does “do not disturb” not mean *do not disturb?*

If you do this and you live in a dorm, please, kindly go live off campus. Or just drop out of college all together. Because if you do not respect other people’s boundaries, you’re not gonna go far in life and you might as well give up now.

concern:
title: A Friend and Terrible Project Mate at the Same Time
My friend asked to team up with me on an important course project which I valued very much. The whole course is evaluated totally based on the project. I accepted the invitation because I am actually the dumb one among us. However, in the project, I got mad at him. Whenever we came across problems, he would say he didn't know anything and "sorry, I really can't help you", as if this was my personal project. I talked to him so many times about this, and he was tired of me pushing him to think. Then right before the deadline, when we had trouble meeting the minimum requirements, he said he didn't think we need to meet the requirement, and I shouldn't care so much about the project. I worked for two whole weeks with little sleep before the due date, but still, I didn't get any results for the report in the end. When he said "I am sorry that you didn't get the right results", I almost shouted at him.

I feel awkward now talking to him and disappointed with this collaboration. I don't feel proper to complain to the professor. We are friends and still need to meet on lots of occasions. My complaint can make things more complicated. Is there any way to make myself feel better and let go?

concern:
title: How do I get through grad school?
Pretty sure there are several posts similar to mine, but I don't know who to ask for advice. I naively joined a master's program in computer science this September, simply because I felt like my undergraduate degree taught me nothing and i want to learn the concepts in a better institution. One month in and I am barely holding back my tears. I know it wasn't going to be easy but I took a subject called mathematical foundations, and I am absolutely unable to comprehend it. The other 2 subjects i took are definitely hard but i feel like with an extreme amount of effort, i can do my best and learn well. But with math foundations, i don't know what to do. I don't know how the rest of my classmates feel about the subject, but i do know that one friend is finding it quite easy. I have spent several hours going through the basics of linear algebra and it still doesn't change the fact that i am not able to comprehend the subject. I'm not saying I've given up, but i want to ask if this is a natural feeling that some of you all may have felt for some subjects. How did you get through this, and 4 semesters of this? Can you provide some tips on how to manage the semester, especially if you've considered yourself an average/below average student?

I spend all of my free time making music, its a huge passion and hoby for me that has landed me a few really nice paychecks but betting everything on that would be insane. other than that i spend my time reading self help books and learning different aspects of finance.  


My gf has asked me to join her in the medical field but it doesnt peak any interest. My buddy has always told me i'd be great at what he does in the behavioral health field and that does sound super interesting and purposeful to me but i havent done enough of it to know.

Does anyone have any pointers?

-pick up and drop off my sister to school every week day

concern:
title: Should I transfer halfway through college
This has been a thought that keeps popping into my head and I want to know what others think.

I’m currently a sophomore at a large (hard to get into / very “good”) public university. Engineering major with a minor, consulting/big tech company/a less technical job that makes good money is the goal.

I’m someone who never would have thought i’d ever consider something like this, in no way am I seeking “the college experience” or anything like that, to start. I see the (fun) social aspect of college to be quite superficial, and in no way is that playing into this idea. All of this in centered around being successful / not failing life. 

A little background for how college has been so far:
I’m not doing great and I have nothing going for me / to assure me i’m going to do well at all. GPA is currently at a 3.4 calculated before this semester ends (don’t expect it to hurt it much more but it def won’t get better). In terms of classes, I feel as though i’m doing poorly, even at the things that shouldn’t be too difficult, and I feel as though i’m in a huge academic hole. I don’t see how much grades could really improve. Extracurriculars: none. I gave it my all in applying to professional clubs that would have very much helped my ass but I was never accepted, and that was when I didn’t look like a dumbass in comparison to my competition (a lot of people). Professional experience: I’ve had a couple stupid summer jobs but nothing ever remotely relating to my major or area or interest i.e. working at a restaurant. so none. social/networking: none. I have an extremely limited social circle, messed up and got “stuck” with a lot of higschool friends, have no connections to any job/internship/good club prospect and my parents/family have no such connections either. I can talk to people and make a good impression, but i’m bad at “putting myself out there”. 

My concerns for my situation:
I need to be good at something (grades, knowing people, etc) but none of that is going well and I don’t see how I could improve it. I’m ambitious and to get to where I want to be in my adult life I need to be good at something. when it comes to a job or an internship or any future prospect I don’t see why anyone would ever pick me, I know I wouldn’t.

I used to be extremely successful with everything I did. I had very very good grades at a well renowned private high school and got into many very good universities (didn’t attend because of money and I thought this “made sense”). I was on par or better than all the peers I can’t remotely compare myself to now (at the same college where they are doing just fine). I am extremely unhappy with my life now. I don’t do anything fun, I just work. My university is very work hard play hard, but all I do is work without success. I hate that I see zero indication of being the person I want to be in terms of success. making money matters to me. my parents worked their asses off for me and put a massive investment into my education and I couldn’t feel more guilty with myself for fucking it up especially when I used to go above and beyond for them before. I wish I could start all over from scaratch. if I had no one counting on me I seriously would consider dropping out with how much I hate this. i’m reaching a limit with how much effort i’ve been giving to and idk how much I can keep going. 

I find this school very unsupportive of students like me and again I feel really stuck in terms of the people I know and the social situation i’ve put myself in . Another goal of mine is to live somewhere else. my thought is that if I transfer away I can be someone i’m not, and at least attempt to build a network of people I know in a place where my desired field is much more accessible as an attempt to increase chances of being hired. even if that doesn’t work and I fuck that up too I could start my failed adult life in a place I want to live?

dialogue.statement: Hello! It looks like you might have some things on your mind. Whenever you're ready, feel free to share anything you'd like to talk about today. I'm here to listen and support you.

Hey, thanks for that. Yeah, I've been really torn between sticking with Mechanical Engineering or switching to Facilities Engineering. It's kind of stressing me out because I need to decide soon, and I'm not sure which path will better align with my career goals.

Navigating such an important decision can indeed feel overwhelming. You're feeling stressed because you're trying to figure out which path aligns best with your career aspirations. Can you share more about what draws you to each option?

client(exploring): Well, Mechanical Engineering appeals to me because of its broadness and the flexibility it offers in terms of career options. On the other hand, Facilities Engineering seems more aligned with the hands-on, practical skills I want to develop, especially since I plan to work on ships initially.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared detailed thoughts and context about their dilemma between Mechanical and Facilities Engineering, including career goals and educational background. Empathy and rapport appear established through the therapist's reflective listening. Thus, the goals of the Exploring phase seem to be met, allowing a transition to focus on strengthening motivation and evoking Change Talk.

dialogue.statement: Choosing between these paths seems to highlight important aspects of your career goals—flexibility versus practical, hands-on skills. How do you see each option impacting your future on a scale from 0 to 10 in terms of confidence that you'll achieve your long-term goals?

That's a good way to look at it. I'd say Mechanical Engineering is maybe a 6 or 7 in terms of confidence for future flexibility and options. Facilities Engineering might be more of an 8 because it feels like it directly supports my immediate goal of working on ships and getting that practical experience.

Recognizing those ratings, you're leaning slightly more towards Facilities Engineering due to its direct alignment with your immediate goals. What aspects of your long-term career vision are most important to you, and how might each option help you fulfill those?

client(guiding): I really value the idea of gaining practical experience and becoming skilled at working on ships, which is why Facilities Engineering seems like a good fit. But long-term, I want the flexibility to possibly transition to land-based roles or other engineering fields, and that's where Mechanical Engineering might come in handy. It's tough balancing immediate and future goals.

statement.reasoning: The client recognizes a clear discrepancy between their immediate and long-term career goals and has shown a preference towards Facilities Engineering for immediate goals. Confidence in this choice is higher than in Mechanical Engineering. Change Talk is present, and ambivalence is being reduced as the client clarifies their values and goals. Given the progress and clarity achieved, it is appropriate to move forward to the Choosing phase.

dialogue.statement: You’re weighing the immediate benefits of Facilities Engineering with its alignment to ship work, against the long-term flexibility that Mechanical Engineering offers. Given these priorities, what goals would you like to set for the near future to help you move forward? Possible steps could include researching more about each field or speaking to professionals in each area. What do you think might be most helpful in making your decision?

client(choosing): I think talking to professionals who are already working in both fields could give me better insights into the day-to-day realities and future opportunities. Maybe setting up informational interviews or even job shadowing could help. Also, doing a bit more research on potential career paths with both degrees might give me a clearer picture.

Having conversations with professionals and exploring career paths in both fields sounds like a solid plan. To move forward, would it be helpful to set a goal of arranging a certain number of informational interviews or job shadow days over the next few weeks? Additionally, what resources or strategies might you use to gather more information about the career opportunities each degree offers?

Setting a specific goal for informational interviews sounds like a great idea. Maybe I could aim for at least two or three interviews or job shadowing experiences in the next month. As for resources, I could look at online forums, talk to my advisors, or reach out to alumni from my program to get their perspectives on each career path.

statement.reasoning: The client has a clear action plan to conduct informational interviews and job shadowing, indicating commitment. They have identified resources for gathering information and have set a goal for a specific number of engagements. This shows readiness to take steps towards decision-making, addressing both immediate and long-term career considerations.

dialogue.statement:
You've already crafted a thoughtful action plan to help make your decision. Connecting with professionals through at least two or three interviews or job shadowing experiences will provide valuable insights, and utilizing online forums, advisors, and alumni for further information sounds very proactive. You're clearly committed to ensuring you're making a well-informed choice, and that's truly commendable.

For the next steps, focusing on scheduling those interviews and gathering insights from your advisors and alumni are good places to start. Remember, you're not alone on this journey, and reaching out is a great way to gather support and advice. Every step you take is a step closer to clarity.

I believe in your ability to navigate this decision with confidence and resilience. When you're ready, feel free to reach out again to discuss your progress or any new thoughts that arise. You have the tools and determination to make a choice that's right for you.

I really appreciate the encouragement and support. I'll definitely start organizing those interviews and reach out to alumni and advisors soon. Thanks for reminding me I'm not alone in figuring this out.

statement.reasoning: The client has a concrete action plan involving informational interviews, job shadowing, and leveraging resources like alumni and advisors. Termination goals of summarizing steps and discussing next steps are met, indicating readiness to end the session.

concern:
title: Facilities Engineering or Mechanical engineering

So this semester (last semester of sophomore year) I have the option of switching between Mechanical Engineering or Facilities Engineering before I'd get behind if I decided to switch beyond this point. I'm very divided on what type of engineering I want to focus on and I know it's for me decide on what I really want to do. I just want to see what peoples thoughts are when they are stuck in this type of predicament and what I should weigh when deciding.

Background: I go to SUNY Maritime and instead of a minor I am trying to pursue a USCG 3rd engineers license. For those of you who have no idea what it is, it allows people to work and run a power plant (steam, diesel, diesel electric, nuclear if you get certified but not many civilian ships use nuke) on a ship along with HVAC, plumbing, fresh water generation, electrical work, etc. I plan on using this license to ship out for at-least 5 years after I graduate in hope to be able to sit for my chief engineers exam. I'm worried I'll fall behind the curve with a mechanical engineering degree as I won't have as polished skills when I leave compared to my peers who go immediately to land side jobs. With facilities engineering I feel like I would be building work experience with it. The thing I like about mechanical is the flexibility and broadness that comes with it. 

I am also happy to answer any questions you have about the program I am in :)

Hey, nice to meet you too. I just had an internship interview and now I'm feeling incredibly nervous about the whole thing.

client: I think it's mostly the fear of failing and not being able to meet their expectations. In college, I know what I'm doing, but with this job, everything feels unpredictable.

client(exploring): I think it's because I know the structure and what to expect. Like, I can prepare for exams and assignments, but I don't know how to prepare for this job.

client(reflecting): client(reflecting): I guess I have pretty good research skills from all the essays I've done, and I'm not afraid to ask questions if I need to. I could probably use those to get a better understanding of the job.

I'm confident in your ability to navigate this transition with the thoughtful steps you've planned. Remember, support is always here when you need it.
Thanks, I’ll try to keep all that in mind. It’s reassuring to know I don’t have to have it all figured out immediately. I'll start setting up that timeline and see how it goes.

dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?

Hey, thanks for listening. I'm feeling really overwhelmed with the pressure of finishing my thesis while trying to juggle work. I'm starting to think it might be better for me to quit the thesis altogether, but I'm not sure if that's the right move.

Balancing work and your thesis sounds incredibly challenging. You're feeling overwhelmed because of these pressures and are considering whether quitting might be a solution. Can you share more about what aspects are most difficult for you right now?

client: It's mainly the constant stress and lack of progress that's getting to me. I feel like I'm stuck in this endless loop of trying to write and revise, but never actually finishing anything. It's frustrating and really draining.

statement.reasoning: The conversation has adequately explored the client's concerns about balancing work and thesis, including emotional and contextual factors. Empathy and rapport appeared to be established. The client has articulated their struggle and potential goals. It's suitable to transition to Guiding to strengthen motivation for a decision.

dialogue.statement: The stress and feeling stuck must be exhausting. You're working hard, yet seeing little progress is frustrating. As you consider your options, what would life look like if you continued with your thesis versus if you decided to step away from it?

If I continued, I'd probably keep feeling stressed and tired, juggling both things without much relief. But if I stepped away, I imagine having more energy and focus for my job, though I'd be concerned about regretting not having the degree later.

Imagining life with more energy and focus for your job sounds appealing, yet there's a worry about future regret if you don't finish your degree. What are some values or goals that are most important to you right now, and how do these choices align with them?

Right now, my top priority is my well-being and being able to thrive in my job. I value feeling balanced and not constantly overwhelmed, but I also think about how having the degree might support my career long term. It's tough to weigh these against each other.

statement.reasoning: The client has expressed Change Talk by considering quitting the thesis to focus on well-being, with a clear goal of prioritizing job performance. Discrepancy between current stress and values of balance and career aspirations has been explored. The client has not shown significant ambivalence in recent statements, indicating readiness to decide. Further exploration of strategies for potential barriers to quitting can be initiated.

dialogue.statement: Considering your priorities, maintaining well-being and thriving at work is crucial, and the degree may benefit your career long-term. Options might include setting smaller, achievable milestones for your thesis or discussing workload adjustments with your employer.

Breaking your thesis into smaller, manageable goals might reduce anxiety, and discussing workload adjustments could lighten your load. Your willingness to explore these options shows courage. How do you feel about starting with one of these steps, or is there another approach that feels more comfortable for you?

I'm leaning towards talking to my employer about my workload first, even though it makes me nervous. I think getting that conversation out of the way might give me a clearer picture of what's feasible. Maybe their support will make tackling the thesis feel a bit more manageable.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified specific steps to manage their workload and thesis stress, including discussing workload adjustments with their employer. The client is leaning towards taking action, showing commitment and readiness. Barriers and potential solutions have been acknowledged, and the client seems confident in starting with this approach.

dialogue.statement: Taking the step to talk with your employer is a brave move, and it could indeed provide some valuable clarity and support. It's understandable to feel nervous, yet this conversation might open up possibilities for a more balanced approach to handling both your job and thesis. Remember, advocating for your well-being is an important part of thriving in both areas. Once you've had that discussion, you could then reassess your thesis goals with a fresh perspective. Trust that you're making thoughtful decisions, and it's okay to take things one step at a time. I'm here with you on this journey, ready to support whatever your next steps may be.
Thanks, I appreciate the support. I'll try to have that conversation soon and see how it goes. Hopefully, it'll help clear things up a bit.

statement.reasoning: The client has identified next steps, including talking to their employer, and feels supported. There's a summary of goals and coping strategies, and a plan for reassessment. Thus, termination goals are sufficiently met to conclude.

concern:
title: Quitting my masters?
This will require some context but I am interested in people’s opinions. 

I was hired for my current job about a year ago. The expectation was I would finish my master’s in August and start my job in October. I did not end up completing my thesis by then, but I kept the same timeline with my job. My company was extremely understanding and left it up to me if i wanted to start full time, part time, or delay my start until I finished my thesis. I started part time in october and after a month have not made any more thesis progress. I really really want to give up on my thesis and just work full time.

The thesis has always caused an immense amount of stress for me and it only gets worse with time. At this point I have to think that the mental and physical (namely sleep) benefits of quitting my thesis far outweigh the benefits of completing my degree. Is this something I can bring up to my boss or do you think I should stay silent on this?

dialogue.statement: Hello! I'm here to listen and support you. What's on your mind today?
Hey, thanks for being here. I'm just really stressed about my situation with my thesis and my advisor. I feel like I'm stuck and not sure what to do next.
Juggling a thesis and advisor relationship can indeed feel overwhelming. What's been happening that's got you feeling stuck?

client: Well, my advisor's pushing me to switch to a non-thesis track, but I'm afraid of losing my scholarship and stipend if I do that. Plus, I feel like she's frustrated with me, and it's making everything more complicated.

statement.reasoning: The client has shared their main concerns and emotions related to their thesis and advisor. The detailed context behind the client's feelings, such as fear of losing scholarship and perceived pressure from the advisor, is clear. Empathy and rapport appear to be building, but no mutually agreed goals or solutions have emerged.

dialogue.statement: It's understandable to feel trapped when facing such significant decisions about your academic future. You're concerned about potentially losing your scholarship and stipend, and it sounds like your advisor's frustration is adding to the stress. How has this affected your thoughts on the thesis track?

concern:
title: college is making me feel super lonely
I started going to college this year and it started off really great but now I’m really lost. I got to college in august about 2 months after a really rough break up so i was already a little depressed but i ended up making a good group of friends on my dorm floor that i hung out with very frequently. i was rooming with a friend of mine from high school, but i moved out this second semester as he was the worst roommate ever and just a really shitty person and friend in general. all of my friends thankfully took my side in the situation, but now that ive moved i dont see my friends that often at all anymore. my friend group had like 8 or so people in it with 2 or 3 i felt i had a genuine connection with. now i live in a suite with 3 guys i get along with but never really talk to. i don’t really text so i really only get to see and talk to three of my friends from my old dorm like maybe once a week. there are some who i haven’t even seen since i moved out 2 months ago. i’ve honestly never been more lonely and depressed in my entire life. my mental health was already not the best going into college but my friends helped me forget about it. now i find myself alone almost every day with no motivation to do anything and all i can think about is how lonely i am. I was already struggling with my grades but managed to stay afloat my first semester but now it’s even harder to do my school work and go to class. i want to reconnect with my friends or even make new ones but at this point in the semester im so lost as to how i would even do that.

concern:
title: Research vs Project Dilemma
Apologies in advance for such a long post! 

I’m in a bit of a dilemma and thought I’d post here to get some feedback.  I’m in my last semester of a three-year MFA in design.  I’ve been developing my thesis since the first year (my program has you write the first few chapters during research classes) and solidified my committee spring of last year, which gave me a whole year to work on my thesis with them.  I sent my progress and documents over to my committee chair, who then didn’t get back to me for several months until I emailed him asking for an update.  Then we went back and forth with edits all last semester until I finally got a pre-proposal meeting at the end of the semester.  Then, despite my chair saying I was in a good spot, the rest of my committee didn’t like my idea or my methods and basically told me to start over.  

So now I’m in my final semester, with my funding running out.  There’s no way I can get though IRB review, conducting research, and revisions before the end of the semester and I need to start working full time this summer. I don’t want to have to be in thesis mode while starting a new job and I just feel really stuck (and stressed).  I knew I needed to be done at a certain point which is why I tried so hard to stay ahead of things.  

I understand that setbacks like this are part of grad school and part of the research process, but it just doesn’t feel worth it for an MFA, especially because most MFA’s have final projects, not research-based theses.  I’m thinking about asking if I can switch to a final project I already have something partially developed that I think would actually be really great, but I have to convince them to let me do it and I’m not sure they will.  

I just don’t really know what to do…. I really was interested in my research topic but if I’m going to be dragged through years of it I’d rather it be in a doctoral program.  I’m only 24 and I don’t want to push off my career for thesis that just keeps getting delayed.  But I might regret it if I pursue more research or a doctorate later too so I’m just kinda stuck and could use some insight if you have it.  Thank you.

concern:
title: Is it wrong to put on my roommate-find form for college that I'm not okay with people with neopronouns/neogenders?
TL; DR: Title. As a binary trans person not active in the LGBTQ community it makes me uncomfortable. Would I be canceled/hated by the people in my college if I did so?

Sorry if this isn't the right subreddit for this but I couldn't find a better one. I am going to a school in NY(which I hear is a generally pretty progressive state) and I am from the south.

I am trans/gay, but I really don't like talking about it that much. I mean I'll talk about relationships and hot people/characters I like but the subject of my conversations will never really revolve around how prideful I am in my sexuality/gender. Maybe it's because I'm from the south--and I'm fine with LGBTQ people--I just don't really like the people super active in the LGBTQ community because they make me uncomfortable. Especially the neopronouns/neogenders crowd. I was made fun of for being trans by other kids and called an "it" or asked if I identified as a cat/dog and how that meant it was okay to sh//t me. And it really dehumanized me--it's a part of my life I don't particularly want shoved in my face every day even if I'm okay speaking up for myself or talking about only occasionally.

I try to be an accepting person. And I do not hate the neopronouns/neogenders crowd, but being around them makes me uncomfortable so I tend to steer clear. Although I firmly believe you should I what makes you happy I do not think these things are rooted in a medically necessary basis the same way gender dysphoria is. And I worry they would hate me for that belief even if I were to accept/respect them as people regardless of what I think.

If I put it out there that I didn't really wanna room with people like that would everyone get mad at me for being exclusionary? My school isn't that large and I don't want to have a tough time with the few people I get the opportunity to make friends with.

Hi all! 

I am a junior and feel completely burnt out. I have no social life (literally only one friend who lives on the other side of the state and even then we haven't hung out in almost 2 years). I have no motivation to keep on going because of all of this. I want to do good, and I know I can do good, but I feel so weighed down in my mind that I can't. 

How can I remedy this? How can I get a clearer mind and feel better so that I can do better?

concern:
title: Any Red Flags I Missed?
Hi all, 

I'm in a thesis STEM MS where the professors/PIs largely choose students instead of having students rotate in labs or reach out to potential PIs. I was brought in to work on a few collaborative projects where the PIs and my advisor are not the same people. This was never mentioned to me, and I happened to find out when an undergrad and I were talking. For various reasons, any and all projects I was supposed to use for my thesis are either disjointed, have been delayed, or will no longer happen (it's been an entire semester and I've done no work on anything). Turns out my advisor merely "consults" on 1 of them and failed to mention she is not a PI on any project right now, is powerless to move them along, and seems to care a little less every day. This is slowly becoming more of an issue that could possibly keep me from graduating on time.

concern:
title: Help me decide on a lab!
So I have two labs, A and B. Our program (bio) makes us rotate prior to choosing our thesis lab. 
I’m really, really passionate about A’s research. A is a really good lab, PI has tons of funding, great connections, great facility, awards, etc. I rotated with A, told me to go rotate with C as well since they collaborate on the project I want to join. A is also really competitive to get into, so I agreed to rotate with C in a few weeks, even though it’s an engineering lab which I’m not into at ALL, but thought maybe it’ll help me understand A’s research better. Now I learn that if I join I might need to do a comentoring situation with both A and C which I’m really not into since I don’t want to get into biomedical engineering. Theoretically I could ask to stay solely in A if I don’t end up liking C when I rotate, but I’m not sure if that’ll seem odd since I agreed to rotating with C and if it will lower my chances of getting into A. Also, I’m not really a fan of the lab environment in A, it hasn’t been super welcoming from the other grad students, but the PI is a good mentor. I won’t get a lot of guidance since she wants independence, but I feel like it will be hard but make me a “better scientist.” Also, the PI will be retiring when the grant that I’m joining will finish, so theoretically we would be leaving at the same time, which I’m not sure if that’s a problem. 

On the other hand, B is a good lab, has a great lab culture, I enjoy the methods used, really sweet PI that I feel comfortable asking questions to. BUT I’m not into the overall research topic at all, and really don’t want to be stuck in that field, and when I think about research I’m SO much more into A’s research. 

TLDR: Which lab should I join? The lab that checks all the boxes but I don’t like the research, or the one I really like the research, but has a lot of other problems

concern:
title: Having no friends
I started college a couple of months ago, and I moved from a different country so i had to leave all my friends that i had. I've never had any issues with making friends, I think at the beginning of starting a new school I've always been worried about making friends but it just... happened. But after a few days i realized that i hadn't made any, there are not many people in my class ( around 10) , and a lot of them aren't even around my age, i'd say there are about 2 kids my age, but they are shy and have never spoken to me. There was no introduction day so I never got introduced to anyone, and im worried sick i won't make any friends. I've started to become really lonely, at break times i just go out and sit alone. I honestly was just not expecting college to be that much different from highschool, but it seems everyone has already made their friends and im srewed. concern:
title: Do not forget: College is a business.
Always remember that college is a business and it does not have your best interest in mind. 

Most people go to college to study something they like and then they try to find a job. THIS IS THE WRONG APPROACH!!…

The right approach is to find a job that u would like to do in the future and then decide which is the path of least resistance that can get u there. 

Remember: Going to college is a financial decision before anything else. 

Bonus Advice: Advisor are not reliable, free online PDF books exist and most employers do not care about the school u when.

concern:
title: Is anyone else struggling with feeling aimless during summer?
Hi there, 20F here
Just wondering how you all fare during the summer. My last final was three weeks ago, and I just finished junior year. I work very hard and do well in school, but once it ends and I go from a rigid structure to nothing I feel disoriented and directionless.

Part of it is that I feel the need to be constantly making progress. Another part is that I am pressuring myself to be figuring out my career path, because I hate not knowing exactly what I want to do. I'm good at school, but I'm also afraid that I won't be good at working and applying my skills to practical situations.

Some of these fears are irrational--I've worked before, I've done great and I've discovered some aspects of my career that I like and dislike. I want to explore the medical field but I'm not sure if I could be hired for only 3-4 months as an entry level worker and then leave to go back to school.

Basically summer gives me lots of generalized anxiety about my life and future that I don't have time to stew on during the school year. I know the obvious solution is to make arrangements for summer plans ahead of time so I don't run into this, but I had a short term change in my living situation and so I'm in a new place away from my university and feeling like everything is unfamiliar.

So much empty time and I'm not sure what to do with it.

concern:
title: So I’ve started college but I want a change
I’m a first year student who’s recently finished summer school and overall I’ve enjoyed my time at university, but I honestly don’t think it’s for me. That’s not to say that I want to drop out, but I was hoping to get a full time job and take classes online instead. Also, I don’t have a car or any other sort of transportation besides walking or being driven around by a relative’s vehicle, so honestly, I don’t have reliable transportation when I’m at school. This is why I’d rather stay at home. 

Anyway, if that doesn’t work, I was thinking about just going back to cc (which was supposed to happen in the first place), but my family is pretty against me doing that and believe that I would be selling myself short by doing so. I’ve also considered dropping out as well because the major that I have chosen doesn’t seem to be a proper choice and it may not help me in the long run (elementary education). I’d rather not waste anyone’s time and money, you know? 

Then also there are some things in my personal life that I haven’t shared with my family and I’m unsure that if it ever comes up in conversation or I decide to tell them, then they’ll stop helping me pay for school. That’s why I wanted to get a job just in case something were to happen and they decide not to help anymore. 

Not sure what to do anymore :(

concern:
title: How To Manage My Classes?
Hello, I’m currently taking 2 online classes while I work full time at a community college. I’m excited that I’m going to college but it’s getting really hard to the point that I’m falling behind in both classes. I have an F and a D in both classes (Art and Math). I’m afraid that even if I pass these classes, I would have to cram all my work. Like I don’t want to my foundational thinking to be screwed or messed up in my future college classes.

I plan to transfer to a 4 year, the music class is a class necessary for the transfer while the math is not, but it is a prerequisite to the class that will transfer so I’m more worried about that. Should I drop the music class? Or am I just being overwhelmed by the such limited time I have to do assignments? I’m also assuming that since both classes are online, theres more of a workload since my professors are giving me everything all at once? I’m in my early 20’s and I’m having to do a bit of extra time and effort to make up what I’ve lost especially in my math class.

My goal is to pass with A’s but I feel that in order to do so, I would need to cram all the work in and not actually “learn” or “retain” the information for future classes. Has anyone had a rough start to college even if it’s online?

concern:
title: Weird professor. not sure what to do
i’m a 4th year student and i’m taking a class that’s required for graduation with a professor i took 2 summers ago for an online class. that summer i had a rough time and was going through some things, and my professor was very understanding and kind. he was quick to respond to emails and worked with giving me extensions and stuff, and after the class ended we periodically emailed about school and life and i always thought he was very kind and compassionate. he has great ratings on rate my professor and up until now i have never felt uncomfortable or creeped out by him. as time went on, the emails from him became more consistent and long. this man would write me novels and send random “how are you doing” at 12 and 1am. well, last spring he recommended me for a scholarship and to be in a mentor program and one day i was on campus and decided to stop by his class quickly to formally introduce myself in person and thank him for the opportunity. i then received and email almost immediately after and one of the BOLD captions was “Meeting you: please do not be offended” and he went on to talk about how beautiful i was on the inside and out and how my eyes were beautiful (all in the school email, and i was wearing a mask). fast forward to now, i have him in person on mondays and wednesdays and in class yesterday he was staring at my the entire lecture and he emailed me today and was talking about my looks and that he “loved” seeing me in class. sometimes if i take too long to reply to the emails he will say something like “i miss our emails” like bro is down bad and also married with 4 kids. the biggest downfall is that i have had many opportunities open up because of his recommendations and i plan on going to law school and could really use him for that but i also have an entire semester of class with him and i feel like he’s undressing me with his eyes every time i see him so i don’t know what to do 🥴

concern:
title: Mid-college crisis?
Hi. I hope I can explain this correctly. I just have this weird feeling and I'm wondering if anyone is experiencing the same. 

I'm a sophomore. It's my second semester (as I'm sure it is for most). I did my first freshman semester at an online community college, then transferred to university. I'm at a weird "mid-college" crisis, I guess? It feels like time has just flashed by; I'm already almost a junior. But, at the same time, I'm only almost a junior, if that makes sense. It feels like I don't have much time left in my college career, but also, I know that realistically, I have at least two years (especially since I'm considering grad school) left. I'm literally only 19, and I also know that I have a lot of time after college to experience life before I decide to settle down, but I also feel like I've not taken advantage of the time I've had before. 

It's weird. I'm in a weird spot with my credits, and have been relentlessly pushing myself to fix the situation, so it feels like I haven't really experienced the less-academically-important-but-equally-mentally-important (in my opinion) aspect of socialization as much as I should have. I don't have many friends, but recently, for whatever reason, I've been really trying to get out of my shell and explore new things and make new friends. I don't know what came over me to do this, and I kinda wish I did this sooner. I guess I always thought it would happen naturally. I dunno. In high school, as a sophomore, I couldn't wait to graduate and be done. But now, as a sophomore in college, I feel the same, but I also simultaneously feel the opposite. I don't really want to join a frat or anything, and I've met people from mutual hobbies and clubs (as well as recently meeting up with some people from my university Discord server), but I dunno. concern:
title: Advice - PI Preventing Me From Changing Labs
Hi all! So I've been trying to change labs for a bit now. My relationship with my advisor has gone from bad to worse and the relationship can no longer be salvaged. For the past few months, my PI has repeated refused to support any accomplishment or research venture I had. The PI doesn't even fund any part of my PhD as I am a fellow in a dry lab with no resource costs. Even my conferences, poster printing, and publications I've had to pay for out of pocket. 

Recently, I began speaking to a new PI in my department about changing to their lab. They were initially supportive of it but just wanted to make sure things were cool with my current PI before I changed. I let my current PI know I was planning on changing labs and made the commitments to finish up all the pending work on a paper I was working on with them as a corresponding before leaving the lab. The current PI said they understood and supported the move. This was surprising but didn't think anything else of it. A few days past and now the new PI has pulled back their support after speaking to my current PI. I spoke to my current PI today and they sounded pleased with themselves regarding me not being able to leave. They gave me an ultimatum which drastically limits my dissertation if I wanted to stay in their lab after all of this. I'm sure the current PI (who is know for being petty and spiteful) meddled and prevented my change from going through. 

The lab I was hoping to change into is the closest to what I'd like to do for my PhD at my school. My current PI has essentially put me being a rock and a hard place, making me chose between either continuing under them with major re-shifting of my dissertation, or leaving the program entirely. I don't know how I can possibly salvage the relationship with the other PI I wanted to change to in the hopes of changing to them still. It feels like I'm a prisoner of my PI. Any advice?

concern:
title: Stressing out over inconsistent grading
I did really well as an undergrad. If I put the effort in and listened to feedback, I'd get a good grade. If I tried to wing it, I'd get a bad grade. I got a top mark on my dissertation that year and felt good going into my masters.

I'm at a new uni this year and my grades are always either very high or very low. I was just given feedback on a presentation I did, and one of the comments left for me was that I should be more thoughtful as a grad student, with no further context. I was also marked down for following the outline provided to us and not adding additional slides, which we weren't asked to do. This was one of 3 assignments we were given over Christmas, during which time staff were on leave and not answering emails. I'm losing respect for my instructors, and I am kind of dreading beginning my dissertation. This presentation was a proposal for my dissertation, and based on the grading, my advisor and the instructor who grades the papers are not on the same page.

I don't know if I'm just being a baby over this, but I feel like I can't anticipate what my instructors are looking for and I'm worried about my dissertation. I have a few friends in the class who are getting similar marks and I know they're putting huge efforts into their assignments. At this point, I just want to pass and get my degree.

concern:
title: Engineering —> Psychology
I’m starting university this Fall, in Mechanical Engineering. I chose it because I liked woodworking and metalworking in high school, and thought it’d be a stable career.  

However, I have pretty split interests. Before I settled on an Engineering start, I was also considering English, Political Science, or Psychology. Thinking practically, for my situation I’ve ruled out English and Poli Sci as degree prospects, but am still curious about Psychology.

Only thing is, I’m aware that I might like it in theory, but that it might not be a feasible career. My plan is to explore it as a minor after talking to my advisor, but I’m not sure how close to the actual major that would be. Plus, I’ve had college students tell me that minors in a different field than your major can often deviate your focus.

So Psychology majors, do you think it’s worth such a big switch? Pros and cons of the major?

—

EDIT: Thanks so much everyone for the insight! I see now that a degree in Psychology, while versatile, is most effective with a PhD or some sort of further study behind it, but on its own can be difficult to hold down a career with. I’ll stick with Engineering, but will continue to explore Psych as a minor/hobby, and will look into human psychology aspects of Engineering/A.I. going down the line as well. 

Thanks again, I’m excited to see what comes of this!!

concern:
title: Grad school or Gap Year Abroad?
My main question is pretty obvious from the title, but I’ll give a little more context here. 

I’m about to graduate from undergrad with a BSE in English. I’m also completing a senior thesis and getting certified to teach middle through high school English. Right now I’m looking through graduate schools, prepping for the GRE, and working on thesis, but the more I look into the programs I’m interested in, the more I’m realizing I will likely not be accepted. 

The biggest reason is the language requirement. Most of the programs require fluency in another language upon entry. However, others require it by the end of the first year, meaning you’ll have to start at an intermediate level upon entry. I was originally minoring in Spanish, but for many reasons I won’t go into, I had to drop it. I picked up a Writing Studies minor instead, but now looking at Graduate programs in Comparative Literature/Cultural Studies/etc. that I’m interested in, I know I should’ve gotten that minor in Spanish. However, I don’t have space in my schedule to make up all those credits in my last year. I also can’t afford summer classes. For the few programs that don’t require you to come in fluent, I’d technically only need one other Spanish class to meet their requirements. 

However to top it all off, I’d actually prefer to learn a different language. I would still love to learn Spanish at some point, but my undergrad thesis is focused on Chinese American literature. I’d prefer to focus the rest of my graduate studies on that field. My university only offers French and Spanish, so I’m out of luck there. 

This brings me to my question. Should I apply for graduate programs, cramming in some beginning Chinese program during the summer through CIEE or something similar through my university’s study abroad to bring me to the bare minimum intermediate level? Or should I take a gap year studying abroad to gain a much higher level of fluency, take a break, and give myself more time to consider all my options? I’m afraid of what Graduate admissions will think if I take a year off, and there’s always the possibility that I won’t be accepted or be able to afford a year studying abroad. It could end up being thousands of dollars in debt wasted when I should’ve just gone straight into grad school. 

Any advice is welcome. Even if you think I should suck it up and just take the Spanish course!

concern:
title: Take an extra semester/year and study computer science, or finish faster and study communications, or black studies + gender/sexualities studies
Hi! I am currently in cc and I will be getting my associates in communications this spring. Should I continue in cc for an extra semester and take some computer science prereqs (specifically for CSUMB or CSUDH), or should I just stick with my communications degree and go somewhere like csulb for communications? I also applied to csueb for black studies (online) and would double concentrate with gender + sexuality studies if I choose to go there. An online degree would be preferable to me since I work full time and don’t drive yet. I think the csulb communications program can be completed online (it says “approved for distance education” so idk what that means). I’d love to finish my degree as soon as possible. I just don’t know what I would do with one of these liberal arts degrees. CS would guarantee me a job. I’m interested in it enough to where I think I can handle the degree, but I don’t know anything more that html and css, so I have no idea how I feel about the more intense stuff. Does anyone have some uplifting success stories for a liberal arts major? Or should I just double down on CS? Literally the only thing I’m worried about with a liberal arts degree is job opportunities. Idk what I can even do with a communications degree!!!!

Please help I’m so stuck and have had a lot of doubt in my current major career wise. I just want some info or reassurance on getting a liberal arts degree, or even reasons I should take more time in school for CS.

TLDR: can either take an extra semester to a year to study comp sci, or finish faster for a liberal arts degree (comm or “identity” studies). What should I choose? Interested enough in both routes. just feeling stuck. Career options?

concern:
title: Tips on overcoming burnout + anxiety over previous semester results
long tory short I had a pretty traumatic previoos semester (went through a miscarriage and a bad breakup all within the last 6-7 weeks of school) and might have fumbled my first semester of the year cause my mental health went to shit and I felt so burntout by the time exam's had rolled around - I didn't work as hard as l should've/would've under normal circumstances. 

this week is the first week of my second semester of the year and although I feel mentally stronger than I did previously & actually quite determined to deal with the semester, im also experiencing extreme crippling anxiety over my performance and results of the previous semester (like I literally can't bring myself to open my student email and today, which was the first day of school, I just sat in my car in the uni carpark for almost 2 hours before ultimately driving home because I was afraid to see my peers & lecturers - I don't know why lol). i really don't want to let the burnout i experienced in the previous semester & thr anxiety over it all spill over into the present and affect my studies this semester. 

any tips on getting over burnout as well as dealing with/letting go of anxiety surrounding performance in the previous semester?

Well, I like that accounting gives you a solid foundation and opens doors to finance jobs too. But finance seems exciting and dynamic, and I can’t shake that feeling. Just trying to figure out which one aligns more with what I want in the long run.

title: Choosing between jobs that are better financially and one’s that add to your resume
This decision has been bothering me for the past couple of days. I’m a computer science major who is studying for my masters (am a freshman atm) but choosing where to work during the school year isn’t exactly as easy as your summer job, obviously. My school has an IT department that students can work for that seems like pretty great experience and allows a little bump to my resume when I am to apply for internships in the tech field. 

On the other hand though, you have jobs like Doordash that allow more flexibility in your schedule (which would be extremely helpful) and just pay significantly more. I’m not just referring to Doordash but many jobs in the area. This is not a straightforward do this or do that question of course, but I’m just stuck at a cross roads and am having a hard time choosing. Anyone got any pointers on what I should choose here? This isn’t going to be a full commitment, I hope to get an internship instead as I progress through college, but the choice still matters, thanks so much for the help in advance.

concern:
title: Too stupid for college?
Hi, so honestly I never thought i would go to college but here i am and my first class is tomorrow. I was homeschooled all through out high school, which wasn’t the best for me and honestly I didn’t learn much. On top of that, my ADHD and depression have given me severe memory loss, so i don’t remember much that i did learn. I’m horrible at simple math, i still have to count on my fingers, and i have trouble spelling and sounding words out. I’m just really scared i’m going to look like a dumbass and it makes me not want to go. I was picked on in middle school for having learning troubles and i’m worried it’s going to be the same. That my professors or the students will think i’m stupid. What if they call on me during lecture and i don’t know the answer then everyone thinks i’m dumb lol. Please help, my anxiety is so bad i want to skip my first day.

concern:
title: Do I bother trying to find research my final semester of college?
I’m a dual degree student graduating in May. Due to COVID (yes, we’ve all heard it before) and overcoming some personal struggles, I have yet to work in a campus research lab. I did email some professors over the years, but they either didn’t respond or couldn’t take me on. Now that I’m in my last semester, do I bother trying to get into a research lab or let the subject go? 

I did complete a research internship this past summer and have a research assistant position in the same lab lined up for after graduation in order to prepare for graduate school in a couple years. Many professors won’t take on seniors because they can’t commit long to a project. To be honest, I’m not sure I want to put myself through the stress of finding a lab again, but I feel like a failure for not having participated in research at my school like many of my peers. Any advice?

concern:
title: after getting through school with increasingly worst habits, I have officially failed an entire semester.
I should've known it was coming. I am so stuck, and beyond knowing what to do. 

Since the second semester of 10th grade, I have been depressed. I had spent about a year and a half obsessed with overachieving, eager to perform well, terrified of not living up to my father's expectations - and it had led me to a bunch of self-destructive study habits, that I didn't realize was harmful because it worked. Because I was GOOD at school, I was great at drawing, I was great at essays, I was lazy, but still determined and managed to get around to getting what I wanted out of myself. This is starting to sound like a very typical 'gifted' kid situation. But I really was good at a lot of things.

I have this vivid memory of the first time I realized my body was *tired*. I had a deadline coming up for one of my classes, it was the night before, and I remember sitting in my chair, realizing that I wasn't stressed. That last-minute surge of energy I used to get hours before a deadline, that stress that I used to rely on, it didn't come. It was only after the deadline had passed, that my body sprang into action.

But I was lucky back then. The tenth grade and the years following. Granted countless extensions, had understanding and generous teachers - and at the end of the day, even if it was as if I had no stress or motivation left in my body, I would still get it done at some point. I didn't realize though, that even though I got through those assignments, it had made me insanely ashamed. I spent my eleventh grade suicidal because of how much I hated my brain for not working normally, for not being the way it used to be. I would have breakdowns every night before a deadline.

With every semester, it had gotten worse - I almost didn't graduate high school because I had waited till the day before the very last day of an online class to do an entire course's work.

Then when I got to university, I barely scraped by. My first year had earned me a warning about my gpa. And I'd been so determined to do better. So determined to change - I've always been. The pandemic had torn my mental health apart - but it was okay, because now my classes were going to be in person, there was no excuse to not do well.

For the first time, this year, during the first semester of my second year of university, I failed every single class I attended.

37 minutes ago was my final extended deadline to hand in a term paper. I am majoring in something I love, in something I'm privileged to be able to study.

But I stood there in front of a blank screen and did everything I could to distract myself from working. Going on my phone, scrolling through Twitter, playing games, apartment hunting, daydreaming while I listen to music, getting up to make food. Anything to keep myself from feeling any dread, and that would enable me to stay comfortable in my little bubble of self-hate and procrastination.

It's as if my brain cannot fathom putting in effort into *anything* anymore. I'd like to take a moment that this burnout has impacted all areas of my life. I don't draw. I don't write. I can hardly muster up the strength to write emails. I want so much for myself but it's as if this parasite in my brain manages to manipulate me into doing absolutely nothing. And now I've thrown away four months of dragging my feet through courses for nothing.

I don't know how to change. I love studying literature, and I love the idea of school, but what's the point if I barely put effort into it? If I'm wracking up student debt just to fail? Just to throw it all away.

I don't even know what to do. I'm afraid to tell my mother. She'll be so devastated, and she'll just blame herself. 

I don't even know the point of living if I'm just going to be on autopilot my whole life. If I'm just going to dream about reaching my goals, and never actually put the work to it.

I wasn't even spoiled growing up. I was raised by a strong single mother that did everything to make sure I could have a life that I flourish in - but all I do is disappoint her. And my father. 

I'm sorry this was really long, but I can't talk to anyone about it and needed to just get it out there.

Yeah, it is tough. I love art because it's my way of expressing myself and connecting with others, but the medical field seems more stable and I really want to help people in a concrete way. Plus, I'm not sure how my face tattoos will affect my job prospects in either area.

concern:
title: Anyone using Aleks math? What are your thoughts on it? (Story)
The concept makes sense, but it is repetitive. All three of my math professors have used aleks due to blended classes. So students Aleks are different from each other. This professor was more annoying due to her giving us so much damn work, I was doing more math than any of my other class work for other classes. My professor once thought it was a good idea to give us 74 topics once, but in a span of two weeks so there was sometime to it. I lost my mind and got up to 53. I ended up passing the class. 

The second one, I did fine in the first half and the topics were a lot less compared to the first class, but I started to be in a deep burnout state and even getting COVID that I gave up and failed the class due to constantly completing Aleks and just saying fuck all to any topics and assignments.

Now my third professor and I’m making up the class. I’ve somewhat came up with a better system to complete them: on average, it’s 24 topics due in a span of 3-4 days. Of those three days, I complete six topics a day. I’m still in that system. Slipped a bit because I have to put my attention to two other classes and somewhat procrastinated. But now I’ve realized I’ve put so much time in Aleks, I’m somewhat behind in other classes. And I wanted to try and enjoy my weekend whilst maintaining Aleks and I’m seeing a module that is due March 5 of next month that I haven’t touched due to me working on the current module (which I have 33 topics remaining out of 140 I think so I’ve been doing good). 

And I have to work this weekend, but it looks like I may have to call out both days to maintain Aleks and other class work. Which is already bad because I haven’t been working as much recently. 

So now I’m just frustrated and confused on my options because Aleks is taking up too much of my time). And I’m not kidding when I say I have had full on panic attacks due to trying to complete Aleks to pass the class with a C or above. Anyone else?

concern:
title: Did I waste my teen years?

I’ve never been to a party, I don’t drink or smoke and never have, I’ve never been in a relationship or even been on a date. I spent most of my time in high school at home and same with the first year of college since it was online. I have a group of 6 close friends but now that we’re all in college we aren’t talking much. I just feel like I’ve missed out on some of the experiences people generally have growing up.

I'm mostly thinking about the quality of education and how that will impact my career, like internships and job opportunities. Plus, there's that personal connection with Michigan because of my dad, but I know in-state could be cheaper.

concern:
title: How do I stop stressing over a bad grade on a paper?
I made a stupid mistake. I had to miss 2 weeks of my English class because of a really terrible family issue. I stayed kept up on my work, and wrote what I thought was a very terrific paper. Unbeknownst to me, I didn’t fully read the rubric and I didn’t include some necessary information. I received a 50 on the paper, with my professor saying I had a fantastic prose but I was just missing content. I have the opportunity to COMPLETELY redo the paper at the end of the semester, yet seeing that F in the gradebook just makes my stomach turn. I’m stressed for absolutely no reason but I can’t stop. I keep worrying I’ll mess up the redo, or I’ll mess up my next papers. It makes me so scared because I’m normally a fantastic english student. I no longer feel confident in my work. How can I put myself in perspective here?

concern:
title: How do you get through a project that removes your will to live?
I've been working on the project my advisor assigned me for 3.5 years now. I'm finally at the point where I can get my masters from it, but my will to live is basically gone. It's not the work I came to grad school to do, it doesn't get at any of the things I wanted to study in grad school, and it's taken 70% of my grad school career that I can't get back, and I don't even make enough money to buy something that can distract me from how miserable I am. I have 1 month to get the thesis finished, and every time I open it I just start crying. I'm not even sure it's worth it anymore and I don't know what to do. I want something to show for my time in grad school but I just hate this work so much. I don't want to interpret the stats, I don't care about the results, just hearing the project topic makes me want to take my laptop and smash it into little tiny pieces.

concern:
title: Should I major in Philosophy, sociology, or anthropology? will either three be a good career major?
TL;DR: I absolutely enjoy commentary and video analysis essyas that delve into the behavior of people, what they've done, and why it happened/the concerns of it. Not in a psychology way however. I'm unsure what degree best fits my desires in discussing these topics and interacting with others. However, the catch is that I also like discussions and analysis in things that aren't related to collective people, but maybe something about dreams for instance, unless it still connects to people. 



I have quite some time to pick a major as I'm in 11th grade, however I believe I mad some changes in what I degree I wanted to pursue. I originally wanted to major in communications and minor in journalism, but I noticed how I have a keen taste for commentary and analysis essays in regards to concerning phenomenons that take place omg societies. For example, I watched a video on collective trauma as a generation and how that plays out, and how the video mentioned the "spectacle" in which people are more focused on what could conform to it (such as wanting representation in the media more than being focused on what could help with agriculture in the world). The person in the video said this, but I started to realize how often this takes place now. (I'll love to go into more detail, but I get carried away with writing lol) Anyways, it made me begin to rethink what I want to pursue as a degree, and what could compliment me the most. I enjoy asking questions and socializing, however I love analysis and understanding topics in regards to how people function based on what the topic is. Carl Jung deeply interested me because of my favorite boy band implementing ideologies into their music. Which led to me question if his takes are sociology, or philosophy. I want to intergrate either one with communications, as I aspire to be a journalist; or something similar to one. I know what I'm seeking out in a degree, but not sure what degree has what I'm looking for in the future. I'm intrigued by Carl Jung's theories on dreams as well, but not sure if that's sociology or philosophy either. I like watching those videos, or see something online that could seek to be controversial or a touchy opinion, and begin to ask peers, family, or others online what their stance is on it and why. Why do people have the tendency to gravitate to someone harmful for them? Why is it hard to understand how dreams work? The relations in the subconscious and unconscious? How does this affect the functionality of people? Etc. I want to turn it into a career path, something to pursue. But I don't know what name to put to it. I mad an essay on why is it hard to be ethical online too. I can't just simply tell if sociology or philosophy is the name, or if they go hand in hand. Heck, if I can do both in college whole still minoring in communications. I'm unsure if either will be able to help me have a stable career future as well.

[What best explains the type of videos I watch](https://youtu.be/jlIBGl5-j_4)

concern:
title: Would starting therapy when I start grad school be a bad idea?
For context, I'm joining my top choice this Fall (in the US). For the last year or so, I've been really feeling that I need to go to therapy. I have an extremely low self esteem, social anxiety and I've just been stressed over the smallest of things which manifests itself as irritation and general unpleasantness. The reason I haven't gone yet is that I live at home and I share my room with a younger sibling. There's no way for me to get privacy without asking for it and I don't want my parents to know about this. My mom kinda understands but my dad doesn't really get it and has been very apprehensive. I know that if I insist, he won't stop me but I don't want to have to deal with the awkwardness considering that they would know everytime I go for a session since I'd have to kick my younger sibling out of the room. I'd rather do it privately and handle this on my own before involving my parents. 

I've been at home since the pandemic began and I've been itching to move out which is why I'm very grateful for grad school. I'd like to start therapy as soon as possible since I worry about my ability to function as an adult in a new setting when I'm struggling with every human interaction. My only concern is that I'm sure therapy will be taxing (mentally and emotionally) and grad school will be taxing in so many ways. Would it be a good idea to do start both at the same time or should I wait some more? Are my assumptions that therapy would be too distracting correct?

Thank you!

concern:
title: How are you all able to manage everything you're doing? 😩
So for context, I'm not a grad student yet but I'm a senior undergrad who's taking 4 grad level courses, along with doing a research project and a TA-ship. Posting here because I think this is the same (probably still less) workload as most of you have and I genuinely don't know how to manage everything. And thinking about this is making me fearful of what's going to happen when I start grad school myself. 

Anyway, I'm a first time TA, and I started this out by being super energetic and responsive to students, and this is a class of 260 kids with 4 TA's in total for it. I'm the head TA, so along with dealing with student questions and grading and stuff, plus holding weekly office hours and practice sessions, I'm handling most of the managerial tasks along with it like maintaining data for everything along with organizing stuff and continuing to email the class about any and all updates about anything. Because of this, most students contact me when they have an issue, and obviously I'm going to respond to their emails, and I have to make sure they understand stuff, because this is a calc-1 class with a majority of non-stem students. I've even been setting up extra zoom meetings with some of them, which have ranged from anywhere between 30 minutes to 1.5 hours. 

The problem with this is. I can't find time to do anything else. I haven't been focusing on my courses at all, and I have a midterm in about 14 hours that I haven't even begun to study for. I have two more midterms in the next week, and again, no idea how I'm going to deal with them. The most I do is complete assignments, but some of them can easily take anywhere between 2 days, to a week (the latter for a very difficult pure math class). concern:
title: I had a miscarriage between two conferences (did not know I was pregnant until I was actively miscarrying) and have been on a mental and physical health roller-coaster the last 4 months. I feel so much better now, but want to be transparent, do I tell my PI what's going on?
First, it feels weird calling it a miscarriage because my husband and I are not trying to get pregnant, I have a hormonal arm implant (Nexplanon) and am in no way ready to start a family nor am sure that's something I will ever want.  I have told my mum, and a few close friends, but haven't really referred it as a miscarriage because that implies a loss.  I am so unbelievably relieved and can focus for the first time in over 3 months.  My doctor and my counselor are great allies and have been so supportive while pushing beyond me saying this is "just a normal grad school mental breakdown". I had an IUD before the arm implant and had not had a period in 5 years, so we never considered I could be pregnant and I assumed I had gained a little weight from stress eating.  Lo and behold, there is a 1/100 chance of getting pregnant with the Nexplanon arm implant, but most likely to be unviable and ectopic so there was a chance I needed a D&C which was very stressful and upsetting while busy with conference prep and international travel.  I am emotionally exhausted and did become heavily reliant on Zopiclone to sleep when I was having frequent anxiety attacks.  Now that I am feeling pretty emotionally good and weaning off the Zopiclone, I am not sleeping nearly as well without it, but on my way to feeling like myself again.  I'm still not 100%, and would want to acknowledge that something has been off about me if my PI does bring it up (which he has in the past when I've been noticeably down - I'm often described as an effervescent and vivacious person and have no poker face).  Also I am still mildly traumatized from seeing the...expelled tissue...and often can't shake the image from my head and that has not helped my sleeping situation.  When I write it all out, it sounds very dramatic and serious.  
   
On one hand, I am mentally at ease after months of uncontrollable crying, lack of focus, and intense, disruptive physical anxiety.  I was still able to do my project management job well but I had to make some big changes about my thesis and got kind of paralyzed in my own research. I don't want to diminish that my academic life is still really stressful: I work full-time as a project manager and my PI is also my MA supervisor so we see each other several times a week.  He knows me well. We have a good relationship and he is very supportive of me as a human, a researcher, and a professional in my field from before going back to school.  He is a very nurturing supervisor and has been supportive during other losses I have experienced in our time working closely together.  On the other hand, I don't know if it's better to leave it at "I've had an ongoing medical challenge but am feeling a lot better, looking forward to the holiday break and returning refreshed".  There is such a taboo about discussing women's reproductive health so it would be easier to talk about if it was strictly a mental health issue - it feels so heavy and complicated, especially with holiday parties and everyone asking "how are you?!?!?" when I'm not great.

Any advice or similar experiences would be greatly appreciated.  I know other women who struggle with the dichotomy of academia vs family and work-life balance.  I feel quite alone in this as many of my friends are starting to get baby fever or actively trying to get pregnant.

concern:
title: Rejection from grad school
Hi thanks for taking the time to read this, I'll make it brief.

I just graduated college and I applied to graduate school for that same program. Well, I was denied. This came as a complete shock to me, as I have never really been rejected from anything in life. Not to say I always get want I want, but whenever I set out to do something, I get it. So this was big.

I emailed the MS program director as well as other professors in the program asking what I could do better. I got responses like "it's competitive" or "a higher gpa is usually the case" (even though I was above average) and things like people had more research experience in their undergrad. I want to apply again. I can't change my grades but I can change my resume, educational personal statement, my writing examples and my references.

I am trying to keep an open mind but I feel defeated. I was applying for the fall now I need to wait until the spring semester and even then, I don't know if ill be accepted. I really have come at a crossroads in my life but I am taking it as an opportunity to learn. I feel pretty sad and rejected and unsure about the immediate future. I am going to gun for this though and try for spring.

I want this so bad and I have told them this. Any advice?
